intro: Suttonia fauriei, commonly known as the New Zealand hound's-tongue, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its distinctive, spiny, globe-shaped fruit that resembles a dog's tongue. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late summer to early autumn. Suttonia fauriei is typically found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and shrublands. It is considered a rare and threatened species due to habitat loss and introduced pests.
